item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Bryce Watt with AJS motorcycle c1966
item.description:
William Bryce Watt (descendant of James Watt, inventor and mechanical engineer) introduced the family to motorcycles. Most males in the family eventually had them and Bryce maintained some of them. Long trips were taken as a family. One couple even going to Italy to meet with people who helped in an escape during the war. Bryce's daughter had a motorbike too and introduced her dad to all her boyfriends so he could fix their bikes!
Donated by: Margaret Mackay
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Two girls on motorcycle c1960
item.description:
Violet Watt and sister Alice Flockhart pretending to ride Bryce Watt's motorcycle. The Watt's are descendants of James Watt, inventor and mechanical engineer.
The bike is a 1952 AJS model 20 500cc twin.
Donated by: Margaret Mackay
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Scammell truck 1947
item.description:
Scammell truck ( 1947) ex. government stock, used in the desert for pulling in broken down vehicles.
Bryce Watt worked for AM Carmichael for many years.
Donated by: Margaret Mackay

item.title: Black Watch Soldier 1902
item.description:
Donated by George McArthur.

The photograph shows John Cochrane Cockburn (03-Dec-1878 - 31-Dec-1935), the donor's maternal grandfather. John Cochrane Cockburn was a regular soldier in the Black Watch and left the army as a Staff Sergeant to return to civilian life. He lived in West Bowling Green Street, Leith. He worked in Tod's flour mill in Bonnington Road.

item.title: Family walking along Princes Street 1932
item.description:

The Reynolds family, Terence aged 10, Cathie aged 3, Terence aged 47, Georgina aged 33 and George aged 2. The photograph also shows the North British hotel in the background and the metal fence, part of which can still be seen today. Taken by a street photographer.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Bristish Rail carriage cleaners c1950
item.description:
Donated by Helen Reynolds.< br />
Helen's mother Georgina is in the middle of the back row and fellow Britsih Railway cleaners. The empty trains from Waverley station went down to Craigentinny sidings to be cleaned. Ordinary carriages and sleeping accommodation. The women worked shifts 06:00 to 14:00 and 14:00 to 22:00 and nighshift.

item.title: Army tents amidst vineyards 1944
item.description:
Donated by John Nolan.< br />
Tents set up amongst vineyards just before Gothic Line.

Note:
The Gothic Line (German: Gotenstellung; Italian: Linea Gotica) formed Field Marshal Albert Kesselring's last major line of defence in the final stages of World War II along the summits of the Apennines during the fighting retreat of German forces in Italy against the Allied Armies in Italy commanded by General Sir Harold Alexander.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gothic_Line

item.title: Signed photograph of Harry Lauder given to Willie Merrilees c1940
item.description:
Donated by Merril Whalen.< br />
Signed photograph given by Harry Lauder to Willie Merriles (donor's uncle) who was Chief Constable for Lothians and Peebles.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Willie Merrilees meets Joan Sutherland c1950
item.description:
Donated by Merril Whalen.< br />
Willie Merriless OBE (donor's uncle) Chief Consatble for the Lothians and Peebles with Joan Sutherland.

Willie had to provide security for Joan Sutherland's visit to Edinburgh.

Dame Joan Alston Sutherland, OM, AC, DBE (7 November 1926 – 10 October 2010)[1] was an Australian dramatic coloratura soprano noted for her contribution to the renaissance of the bel canto repertoire from the late 1950s through to the 1980s
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Willie Merrilees with Roy Rodgers (with camera) and Dale Evans c1950
item.description:
Donated by Merril Whalen.< br />
In the centre is Willie Merriless OBE (donor's uncle) with Roy Rodgers to the right and Roy's wife Dale Evans to the left.

On this visit to Edinburgh Roy Rodgers and Dales Evans visited Dunforth Church of Scotland Children's home which was in Park Road where Willie Merriliees lived. He was a great friend and supporter of the children's home. A little girl named Marion, who lived in the home, sang for them - "Won't you buy my pretty flowers?" which moved Dale Evans to tears. Roy and Dale adopted Marion and took her back to America with them where she grew up and married. She kept in touch with Willie and when he was featured on "This is Your Life" in the 60s she was flown over to see him.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Willie Merriless OBE 1950s
item.description:
Donated by Merril Whalen.< br />
Willie Merrilees OBE the donor's uncle. The printed text on the photograph from left to right reads:

Disguise used in many cases and raids

Chief Constable

Disguise used in arrest of Nazi Spy at Waverley Station, Edinburgh, in September, 1940. Spy later hanged.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Willie Merriless holding the star of Disney's Greyfriar's Bobby 1961
item.description:
Donated by Merril Whalen.< br />
Chief constable Willie Merrilees with the dog who played Greyfriar's Bobby in the film. Willie had become friends with Walt Disney. At the end of filming "Greyfriar's Bobby" the future of the little dog who took the starring role was uncertain. It was given to Willie who brought it home to Edinburgh. He put it in the care of Dunforth Children's home which he often visited.

item.title: Smartly dressed soldier in civvies on leave with his dog c1920
item.description:
Donated by Helen Ewing.< br />
This is my father (John Skene) on leave from the army. He came home and brought his dog with him. It usually stayed at the barracks. He loved his animals - he also loved his white horse. He looked really handsome. My mother had a photograph of him on his horse in full uniform and bearskin. When he brought the dog into the house my mother went daft. When she was young, dogs were kept in kennels outside and she wasn't used to animals in the house.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Brothers in toy car at studio photographers 1936
item.description:
Donated by Helen Ewing.< br />
The boy in the front is Francis Ewing (4 years old and the boy in the back is John Ewing (2 years old).
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Young boy with wheelbarrow made by his grandfather 1965
item.description:
Donated by Helen Ewing.< br />
John Skene, Helen's father, who was part-time caretaker at Pilton nursery. The young boy with the wheelbarrow is Helen's 3 year old son David. 'My father was retired and worked part-time in a nursery. He was supposed to look after the boiler for heating but did many extra things including mending and repairing all furniture, beds, cots, toys and also he made toys for children. He made the wheelbarrow that David is pushing. When we visited he used to take David down with him to play with the other children.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Friends enjoying the sunshine sitting on a wall 1925
item.description:
Donated by Helen Ewing.< br />
The girl in the dark dress was Christine Lothian aged about 20. The other girl was her friend - name unknown. Christine lived in Cramond. The photograph was taken before she was married. She eventually met a soldier at Redford Barracks and had a family. I was her third daughter. She worked in service at this time at a doctor’s house in Colinton. I believe his name was Dr Black.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Royal Scots Grey with army friend 1925
item.description:
Donated by Helen Ewing.< br />
John Skene (Helen's father) in soldier’s uniform. The person in the civvies was his friend in the army. 'The photograph is my father when he was courting my mother. They met at Colinton when she was out walking with the children of the family she was in service with. He served in the Royal Scots Greys. He came from Lybster in Caithness. He ran away from home and joined the army when he was a young teenager. He had drunk the communion wine in the church and his father was very strict.
The minister caught him and he knew his father would take his belt to him when he came home from his job at the railway – he was a train driver. So he took off and joined the army. He lied at the time about his age. He sat all his exams with the army and passed them. He is Stephen’s great grandfather. He won medals during the war and had the oak leaves and a citation from King George VI and also got a mention in the newspapers.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Norton motorcycle 1954
item.description: 'Raymond Skene' s Norton motorcycle. He was 19 years old and really loved his bike. I was his older sister by 2 years and loved riding pillion. My hair was long and we didn't wear helmets then and there wasn't much traffic then either so it was really thrilling speeding along country roads.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Great grandmother, grandmother and mother with new baby 1959
item.description:
Donated by Helen Ewing.< br />
Seated Mrs Lothian great grandmother. Standing to the right is Mrs Skene grandmother. Standing to the left is Mrs Ewing mother. Baby is Christine Ewing.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Pennywell School photograph 1946
item.description:
Donated by Helen Ewing.< br />
Class of Miss Bibb approximate age 10 years in front of headmaster’s office at Pennywell School taken by school photographer who came every year. Helen is in the front row second right in floral dress long blonde hair and ribbon. 'The photograph was taken the first year after the second war world ended. Father was a prisoner of war in Germany. Repatriation home houses were starting to be built in West Pilton. We were allocated a house there to bring all the family together. The school was formed out of houses just off Ferry Road. There was just some fields and some houses there at that time. The houses were four to a block converted into classrooms. Today they are back to being houses.'
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: V.S.O. nurse with Kenyan mother and baby 1971
item.description:
Donated by Nancy McRitchie.< br />
The picture shows Mairhi McRitchie (Nancy's daughter) with a Kenyan woman and her baby. Mairhi was a nurse with the V.S.O (Voluntary Service Overseas). Her patients were from very poor communities where women had very low status. The young woman in the photograph had had two stillbirths and asked if she could stay with Mairhi at the clinic for the last few weeks of her pregnancy. She did and successfully gave birth to a healthy baby daughter. She returned to her community but later came back with her baby for a visit.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Memento of being in the Land Army 1942 - 1944
item.description:
Donated by Janet McKenzie.< br />
During 1942 - 1944 Janet was in the Land Army. 'An Italian prisoner of war (POW) took the photograph. We were not supposed to speak to them. The coloured mount was made with sewing thread. I was in a hostel at Harry Burn House, Lauder. There were 12 of us in the hostel - 8 from Edinburgh and 4 from Glasgow. I was doing field work, which was hard physical work.'
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Couple celebrating their 30th wedding anniversary 1960
item.description:
Donated by Rhona Brown.< br />
Annie (Lindsay) and Charlie Turner taken on their 30th wedding anniversary.
Charlie Turner (1901 - 1973) barber (hairdresser) at their house off the High Street in Portobello where they lived between the 1920s and 1970. At that time Charlie was the longest sole trader in Portobello. Wife Annie, who was a member of the Portobello Thistle Ladies football club - goalie, joined him as a hairdresser in the shop about 1950. Their only child died at the age of 14 in 1945. The wooden bench outside Portobello police station is in her memory.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Portobello Thistle ladies foortball team c1918
item.description:
Donated by Rhona Brown.< br />
Annie Lindsay is centre front with ball (goalie?). Jimmy Lindsay (brother) is the second male from the right. The photograph was taken at Woods (Bottle Works) Park, situated off the High Street behind the old tram depot - opposite the top of Bridge Street.

Annie and Jimmy were two of a family of thirteen who lived near the promenade at the foot is Rosebank Lane - subsequently the site of the open-air bathing pool.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Day trip to South Queensferry with the ferry Mary Queen of Scots approaching c1959
item.description:
Donated by Rhona Brown.< br />
Mrs Annie Turner (right) and sister Mrs Johanne Ramage on a day trip to South Queensferry. The ferry in between the two ladies is the Mary Queen of Scots. The ferry was built in Dumbarton in 1949 and was broken up in 1965.
item.author: Ian ?

item.description: Back centre ( standing) Councillor Stanley Cavaye. On his right (seated) Charlie Turner (hairdresser). Front centre are his nieces: Rhona Lindsay (left) and Anne Ramage. This was on the last tram to run from Portobello to the GPO in Edinburgh.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Girls look on as lady works in back garden c1955
item.description: Mrs Annie Turner with nieces Rhona Lindsay, Anne and June Ramage watching Mrs Winifred Graham working in her in-laws garden. The flat consisted of: kitchen/living room, toilet, 2 bedrooms and sitting room (with ornate cornice).
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: The boat Skylark that ran between Portobello and Inchkeith c1950
item.description: The Skylark ran between Portobello and Inchkeith Island. Passengers were able to stay for 30 minutes on the island before returning to Portobello.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Family and freinds group photograph c1942
item.description:
Donated by Trudy Thomas.< br />
Left to right: David Hutchinson, Olga Kirkwood, David Hutchinson (junior), Robert Hutchinson, Gertie Hutchinson (the donor) and Drummond Gillespie.

My sister's friend Olga worked with her in Harrogate and this was her first visit to Scotland. She loved my sister's kilt and mother, who was a tailoress, arranged to have one made. I am wearing a very old and much too short kilt which I insisted on putting on for the occasion. Drummond had been evacuated to Portpatrick with us and is still in touch with my brother. He lives with his wife in Troon.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Studio photograph of swimmer who only has one leg c1908
item.description:
Donated by Trudy Thomas.< br />
Father was born in 1888 and had his right leg amputated as a child. My sister thinks it was when he was about 4 years old. He became a keen swimmer and played water polo for many years. He was one of eleven brothers, all of whom (apart from himself) fought in the First World War. The youngest was killed in the Somme. He became a tailor and had a business until the Depression.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Family outing at the seaside 1929
item.description:
Donated by Trudy Thomas.< br />
Back row left to right: Anges Smart, James Paton, Margaret Smart. Fron: Margaret Hutchinson.

A family outing.
Agnes Smart and James Paton married about 1932.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Girl on holiday with her new toy pushchair c1925
item.description:
Donated by Trudy Thomas.< br />
Margaret thinks this was taken on a holiday in Dunoon. The pram was a new possession and she thinks her grandfather carried it on train and boat for her to enjoy.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Swimming club outing c1949
item.description:
Donated by Trudy Thomas.< br />
Left to right: Jim Paton, Drummond Gillespie, David Hutchinson, May Hutchinson, James Paton, Andrew Manson and Agnes Paton.

This was a swimming club outing. David Hutchinson held various posts in Fairfield Amateur Swimming Club in Govan, over the years. Was club Handicapper for about 20 years.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Brother and sister evacuated during the War 1940
item.description:
Donated by Trudy Thomas.< br />
When we were evacuated to Portpatrick in September 1939 we lived initially in an hotel in the High Road where about 20 of us, with helpers, were sent. The owner became ill and we were split up and moved to Antrim House where a single lady and her aunt looked after initially 8, then 6 of us. The house is now part of a hotel in the main street.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Father visiting his evacuated children 1940
item.description:
Donated by Trudy Thomas.< br />
Back row: Robert and David (senior) Hutchinson.
Front row: David (junior) and Gertie.

Brother Robert and I were evacuated to Portpatrick in September 1939 and stayed until November 1940. David had gone with us but was sent back the following day as he had Down's syndrome and no one was prepared to take him. My parents visited every 6 weeks or so during that time when a bus brought families of those evacuated. Father was a keen swimmer but I was reluctant to give up my rubber ring.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Glasgow evacuees pose for photograph in front of chicks 1940
item.description: Robert Hutchinson is on the left and Drummond Gillespie is second from the right.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Ladies college 1940
item.description:
The lady 4th from the left is Margaret Hutchinson.

Margaret joined the Civil Service in London at the age of 18 as a shorthand typist. The office was evacuated to Harrogate at the beginning of the War. They went back to London until the heavy bombing later that year and were sent north again. She was in the Ministry of Aircraft Production which was a reserved occupation but managed to get out before the end of the War. She joined the VAD (Voluntary Aid Detachment) and went to Australia to a naval hospital nursing returned POW (Prisoners Of War).

item.title: Members of the Milton Amateur Wrestling Club 1962
item.description:
From left to right: Harry Redpath (Selly), Peter McKenzie (uncle of George Mackenzie), Jimmy Turnbull (light coloured wrestling costume with lion rampant), George McKenzie (Scotland track suit top) were two of the five wrestlers provided by the club for the 1958 Empire Games in Cardiff. The club facilities included a wrestling mat, Ascot gas water heater for shower, "free" weights - no heating and a lot of dedication.
I'm (Jim) on my back, my usual wrestling position, with Ronnie McKenzie showing the hold and George McKenzie (no relation) explaining the hold.

In the second row "adults" Mrs Hamilton McBall Rector of the Royal High School, not known, Mrs McGregor nee Henderson. Both ladies were teachers at the Royal High preparatory school. The land that the Royal High School sat on was later bought by Safeways and redeveloped during the 80s. The playing fields were part of the school's World War One war memorial opened by Prince Henry in 1925.

item.title: Mother with baby standing at gate with gas lamp in background 1937
item.description:
Donated by Maggi and Jim Dignall.

Jessie Klyes Dignall and Jim as a baby.
To the left of the photograph is a wooden fence separating Restalrig Gardens from the grounds of Restalrig House. In the 50s/60s this was replaced by high rise flats used by the fire brigade during World War 2. The building in the rear is the entrance to St. Ninians RC School. The gas lamp was not replaced till the late 50s. It was useful for hanging ropes on to make a swing. Most of the iron railings in the street were removed during World War 2 but the gates were left.

item.title: Mr and Mrs McLaren c1952
item.description:
Donors: Maggi & Jim Dignall.

Mr & Mrs McLaren outside the stair entrance to their flat in Saunders Street, Stockbridge. The flat was lit by gas as was the range fire. Mr McLaren was a retired carter. They had twin daughters Kay and Lucy who migrated to Canada. Kay used the Edinburgh Savings Bank which became the TSB and is now the site of a fast food restaurant at Deanhaugh Street, Stockbridge) to save up their fares to sail to Canada. The fire station was to the west of the flats - further west to Saunders Street was Darling's Buildings with the stairs leading up India Street.

Now all demolished in the 1960s (?)
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Skiers taking advantage of a hard winter 1962
item.description:
Donor Jim Dignall.< br />
Left to right: George Farquhar, Neil Lumsden and James Dignall on the side of Castlelaw Hill the Pentland Hills.
'It was a very hard winter with deep snow - so much so we were able to ski over a totally hidden 5 bar gate. We used to walk the area - we skied from Hillend, before the dry ski slope, to Flotterstone skiing back along the Carlops Road which was blocked by snow.

We were members of the Milton Amateur Wrestling Club at Milton Road Abbeyhill. George Farquhar was tried in the Melbourne Olympics in 1956. He also did two solo sailings round the Horn and also sailed single handed from Perth Australia to South Queensfery Scotland. He is related to the chimney sweep Farquhar.

The skis were hired from Tiso's in Rodney Street opposite the site of the old Ritz cinema.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Staff in a London based composing room 1962-65
item.description:
Ths photograph shows the donor' s (Jean Watt) father Alfred Webster at work. 'He was a compositor and worked at several newspaper/publishing houses - this picture is probably at the "News of the World" or "Daily Express".
I recall he frequently changed jobs - sometimes working nights and part week to accomodate Sunday newspaper deadlines. I believe it was normal to do this within the printing trade. This enabled him to spend a lot of time with us during our childhood, which was probably, on reflection, quite unusual for those times!'
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Kids celebrating V. E. Day 1945
item.description:
Jean Watt (donor), in front row fourth from left sitting.
Informal party organised by neighbours to celebrate V.E. Day. Note the various kitchen chair styles used. Everyone grew vegitables, kept chickens during the war and baked so I expect there would have been plenty of food contributed. Everyone looks very well fed!
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: V. E. Day celebrations 1945
item.description:
Jean Watt (donor) is on the fron row second from the left dressed as a train.
This photograph of Jean Watt was taken at a party organised to celebrate V.E. Day.
My "fairy" outfit would have been made by my mother who was a tailor and would almost cetainly have been recycled from a garment of hers. Given the short supply of materials everyone has made a greate effort to participate and the costumes look good.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: School May Day celebrations 1947
item.description: Donor Jean Watt.< br /> 'A May Day celebration was always held at school on a date nearest to the 1st of May each year. Staff chose the May Queen and attendants - I didn't know what the criteria was! Dresses were used each year and the train was a lace tablecloth. A lot of practice was needed to plait the may pole evenly. Boys usually held the ribbons. Girls wore fresh flowers in their hair.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Group wedding photograph in back garden 1908
item.description:
Donor Jean Watt.< br /> The marriage of Edith and Ernest Webster.
This photograph shows the close family and Edith and Ernest Webster after their wedding ceremony. It was common for the wedding breakfast to be held at home Here they are sitting in the garden for the photographer - note the cabbages in the foreground.

Adults (left to right): Alex Guthrie, Isabel Guthrie, and Margaret Guthrie. The children (left to right): Maureen Bell and Seonaidh Guthrie (donor).
Isabel and Margaret were sisters who by coincidence met and married two unrelated men with the same surname. Margaret and Alex emigrated to Australia with their daughter Lindsey in 1965 for £10 each. It took two weeks by boat to get to Australia. Alex worked for Sandemans at Greenside. Both are now retried and still live in Australia.

item.title: Family of five c1937
item.description:
Left to right back row: David Houston (born 8-May-1905), Nellie Houston (born 25-Mar-1911) and Mary Scott Campbell Houston (born 20-Nov-1930).
Left to right front row: Alec Houston (born 14-Sep-1932) and David James Law Houston (born 14-Mar-1935).
The photograph was taken three years before the donor's (Eoin Houston) father was born - little is known of their life then. The two adults are Eoin's grandfather and grandmother (nee Campbell).
Eoin's grandfather went to work for the elctricity board during the war thus, apart from being a member of the air raid patrol, was excused national service. After retiring he enjoyed two passions: green bowling and model steam enginge making, a self taught engineering hobby.
Eoin's grandmother left school at twelve to run the kitchen on a farm. She used to get up at four in the morning to light the fire. She worked till she married Eoin's grandfather then spent all her time bringing up what was to become a family of five. At the age of 48 she decided to relaunch her employment and became a nurse. She enjoyed making rhymes, often writing poems to celebrate family events.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Man enjoying smoking a cigarette in living room c1960
item.description: The donor's ( Catriona Anderson) paternal grandfather Jack Anderson died five years before Catriona was born. He worked as a chief steward in the merchant navy for the Ben Line Company. He died onboard his ship on one of the trips to the Far East and was buried at sea off the coast of Penang, Malaya. It was to have been his last voyage before he retired.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Lady by fireplace with slippers warming c1960
item.description: This is the donor's (Catriona Anderson) paternal grandmother who died three years before Cationa was born. The photograph was taken in her flat in Piershill Place in Edinburgh. Her parents came from Poland in 1900 but she was born in Edinburgh in 1905. Her father was a cobbler (shoemaker).
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Chartered accountants 1965
item.description: The donor's ( Catriona Anderson) father John Anderson is wearing glasses. John trained as a chartered accountant. The company he was indentured to was JW & RN Oswald and they had an office at 8 Queen Street in Edinburgh where this photograph was taken.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Embroidered post card 1914-18
item.description: This is an example of cards sent from France, where the donor's (Catriona Anderson) great grandfather was stationed during the First World War. He sent them home to his wife Margaret in Leith. The flower is actually embroidered on to the card with threads with at real ribbon attached. They may have been made in Britain the words are in English.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: School leaving guidance card 1934
item.description: The donor's ( Catriona Anderson) maternal grandfather Ben Hendry was given this card on leaving school at the age of 14. He had to go to work because his mother was a widow. No social security in those days. Ben went to Leith Academy School. Then it didn’t matter if you were potential university material. If your parents couldn't afford to keep you on at school - you left and got a job.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Leith Technical College Matriculation Card 1938-39
item.description: The donor's ( Catriona Anderson) grandad had to leave school in 1934 aged 14. His father had died when he was 10 so he had to work. Children (usually sons) only stayed on at school then if parents could afford it. He went to night school at the Leith Nautical College to join the printing trade.

item.title: Helen Ritchie and parents with pet cat 1930
item.description: The stair doorway of the house where the donor's (Catriona Anderson) grandad Ben Hendry was born and brought up. He had a school job in the Primrose Shoe Works deliverying shoes when he was a boy. Every building in Primrose Street was demolished in the early 1970s along with Ferrier Street nearby where Catriona's father John was brought up - the new houses were not an improvement (the donor's personal opinion). Catriona's grandad and Helen's mother were cousins.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Car driver c1930
item.description: Robert Ritchie was the brother of Helen who married the donor's (Catriona Anderson) grandad Ben Hendry in 1986 after her granny died. Robert was in the RAF in the second world war. His bomber was shot down off the coast of Holland. He is buried in Holland along with his fellow crew members. Grandad and Helen have visited the cemetery and were made really welcome by the local villagers who tend the graves with great respect to this day.

The photograph has W M MacDonald, Photographer, Stornoway stamped on the back.

item.title: Looking after the chickens c1930
item.description: John and Lizzie Ross. Lizzie Ross was the donor's (Catriona Anderson) great gran Sarah Fraser's cousin. Both grew up in Skye and Lizzie stayed there all her life. "I never met John he was already dead. But I stayed in Lizzie's house when I was a child in about 1956. Lizzie was elderly then but still had hens."
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Girl beside bicycle 1941
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Girl with rocking horse in back garden 1940
item.description: Marjorie Seaman the daughter if Bella and Chic. They became quite "well off" compared to most working class people. No ordinary kids ever had a bike and a rocking horse then. Marjorie was born in 1931 and is widowed and living in Nottingham.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Boy on tricycle c1950
item.description: One of Bella and Chic Seaman's sons. The donor (Catriona Anderson) thinks this may be the youngest son Gordon. It looks too modern to be the 1930s and I can remember kids having bikes like that. Tricyles they were called or if it was a girl's Fairy Cycles. In which case the picture could be in Bridge of Earn, Perth.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Couple strolling up the North Bridge 1935/36
item.description: Bella and Chic Seaman. This couple were lifelong friends of Catriona Anderson's (donor) gran Flora Fraser. They met in Peebles when Chic worked as a waiter in Peebles Hydro beside Catriona's grandad John Fraser. They all moved to Edinburgh when granny was 14 and stayed all together in a tiny flat in the Lawnmarket (Edinburgh) for a while.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: The festival of the Beltane queen 1932-33
item.description: May Armstrong or Robson a lifelong friend of the donor's (Catriona Anderson) granny Flora Fraser. This is the festival of the Beltane queen still held in Peeble every summer. May was the queen that year awarded becuase she was the school dux. Granny is the first one on the left being the "second top" of the class. She was a lady in waiting.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Beltane festival fancy dress parade 1931-32
item.description: Flora Fraser the donor' s (Catriona Anderson) granny. This is a fancy dress parade with granny and other kids. She is the tallest one and not looking too happy.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: British Red Cross volunteers c1950
item.description: Ben Hendry the donor's (Catriona Anderson) grandad is standing on the right. This is one of the Edinburgh branches of the British Red Cross. The headquarters were in Great King Street. They were all volunteers helping out as first aiders at events in the town. They met each Sunday for ongoing training and competitions with other branches. The men with white caps were senior officers.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Hotel staff c1930
item.description: The man holding the child (not his) is the donor's (Catriona Anderson) maternal great grandfather (John Fraser). He was the hotel porter.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Studio photograph of two youngsters out for a drive 1931
item.description: The photograph shows Majorie Seaman and brother Chicky.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Cat in front of electric fire c1960
item.description: Fireplace in granny Hendry's house. It was built by the donor's (Catriona Anderson) grandad (Ben Hendry) and was the height of fashion at the time. The clock on the mantelpiece is electric (not batteries). It was a wedding present in 1945. Catriona's Mum still has it. Note the portable record player (bottom right) it was like the famous "Dansette" but was actually a Philips brand. The cat was called Cindy - found as a tiny kitten riddled with tapeworm. The family dog Judy adopted her as her pup.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Teenage girl in high fashion c1920
item.description:
The donor's ( Catriona Anderson) granny (Eva Anderson) was a "livewire" as a teenager. She smoked cigarettes out of the toilet window and used to hide her dancing shoes in the bin becuase her parents disapproved of public dance halls.

Special shoes were used for dancehalls to protect the smooth polished wooden floor.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Family group outside their home c1850
item.description: The Todds were the donor' s (Catriona Anderson) great gran's family. 'I don't know which is which, but the house is down beside the harbour at Portree. The sea is a few yards in front of where they are sitting.'
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Broughton High School ski trip 1960
item.description: The donor's ( Catriona Anderson) mother Patricia Anderson (nee Fraser) with her classmates at a school (Broughton High) ski trip in Austria. 'No smart ski suits. Nobody knew what an anorak or salopettes were. Mothers bought woollen trousers and knitted sweaters and provided warm jackets. The boots were hired at the ski slope. We had no previous skiing experience so we all fell over for the two weeks. Travelling there consisted of a train from Edinburgh to London, another train from London to Dover, ferry from Dover to Calais. Then an overnight sleeper train from Calais to Basel. Another train through Switzerland to Austria and finally a bus up a single track road with cliffs on one side and a sheer drop on the other.'
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Soldier's picture of his sweetheart 1940
item.description: Flora Hendry nee Fraser (aged 19), the donor's (Catriona Anderson) granny dressed in her Sunday best. 'Grandad carried this photograph with him throughout the Middle East during World War 2 and the other soldiers thought it was a picture of Queen Elizabeth the Queen mother.'
item.author: Ian ?

He played for Newtongrange Star and also for Fauldhouse (Junior) United. In addition he played two or three seasons for Berwick Rangers.

item.title: Feeding the pigeons during the Second World War 1940-45
item.description:
Front row Alma (donor) and cousin Margaret. Alma's sister Irene is standing at the back.

'This was a scary time to visit London, but my Dad was in the army stationed in Dymchurch, Kent. We all met up in London and stayed at my aunt's house in Waterloo. She was my Dad's sister. We were there on a visit when there were lots of air raids and flying bombs etc.
But is was worth it to see Dad again.'

item.title: Train crash 1914
item.description:
The photograph is from a postcard and on the back was written "Train crash in Burntisland".

The date was not provided with this picture however research has indicated that this is probably the train crash that happened in Burtisland on the 14-Apr-1914 which killed two people and injured twelve others. The cause of the crash was reported to be a signaller error.

item.title: Mother with her children in grandmother's back green 1933

Everyone had the same idea and it took us forever to get to "Porty" from our house in Presentonfield. We had to travel to the G.P.O. first by bus then get the tram car. The queues were miles long!'

item.title: Co-op horse and milk float in the snow c1975
item.description:
" Craiglockhart primary school can been seen in the background. You never forget the thrill of buying your first house," says Norma-Ann Coleman, photograph donor. "Mine was a one-bedroomed flat in a tenement building in Cowan Road and cost £7,800 when I bought it in 1975. There were bungalows on the other side of the road and so I had a clear view over to Craighouse Hospital where, coincindentally, my husband Rob would work years later when the buildings became part of Napier University.
An early memory of Cowan Road was the Co-op horse standing patiently in the street in all weathers while the milkman clambered up the tenement stairs delivering pints of milk.
item.author: Jean

item.title: About to cut the wedding cake 1980
item.description: Norma-Ann Coleman ( the donor) remembers having the sudden urge to do something unconventional during the traditional cake-cutting ceremony. "I thought it was great fun but Rob doesn't look too sure. Touch wood we're still going strong after 23 years (2003) but the premises involved in our nuptials weren't so fortunate. The Registry Office shut down shortly afterwards and is now a gift shop. The hotel in which we had our reception went bust and is now a solicitor's office. Our honeymoon hotel in Paris has been gutted and refurbished - and is no longer recognisable to us. We still have the photographs though to remind us of three places which remain very special to us.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Holiday makers pose for a group photograph c1920
item.description: When he was a wee boy the donor's (Norma-Ann Coleman) father, Douglas Clayton, was playing at circuses with his pal, Angus McPherson. "Angus painted Douglas's face with some unpleasant substance to make him look like a clown. Unfortunatley, or so it seemed at first, his face "went all scabby" and he had to go to the doctor. As well as giving him something for his face, the doctor decreed that the boy needed building up and should have a holiday. So Douglas's mother took him to Rothesay where they stayed in the Windsor Boarding House. For some reason, a group photograph of the guests was taken. Now, all these people were on holiday but there is no casual clothing to be seen. They are all in their Sunday Best and even young Douglas is wearing a shirt and tie for the occasion. His face looks fine so the doctor's prescribed remedy must have worked! Also in the photograph are my grandmother, Isabella Crawford McKay Clayton, her friend Nell Anderson and Nell's father, a pawnbroker from Cambuslang.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Corporal in the Reconnaissance Corps 1945
item.description: Douglas Clayton aged 26, the donor's (Norma-Ann Coleman, father was a corporal in the Reconnaissance Corps during the Second World War. "This photograph was taken shortly after the liberation of Rome and to me his expression reveals something of the anguish and anger of a young man who has just come through the ordeal that was the battle of Anzio."
item.author: Jean

item.title: Four year old boy with wooden toy horse 1923
item.description: Young Douglas was brought up by his mother, Isabella Crawford McKay Clayton, a 'weel-kent' (well known) face in the Royal Burgh of Irvine because she had been a pupil-teacher at the local school. She then owned a sweetie shop in the town and made her own ice cream in the back shop when ice was available.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Studio photograph of baby 1919
item.description: This is an early photograph of Norma-Ann Coleman's father, James Douglas Frederick Edwin Clayton. In later years, we could often see photographs of Dad in the local and sometimes the national newspapers as he sought to attract much-needed new industry to his home town. In the late 1950s as Chairman of Irvine Town Council's Industrial Development Sub-committe, he spearheaded a drive to bring new factories to an area of high unemployment. As a teenager, I remember rushing home on several occasions to see Dad being interviewed on television about the various initiatives being taken to promote the town. His efforts were successful and in 1970 the Royal Burgh of Irvine acknowledged his contribution with the award of one of its highest honours, a Burgess Ticket.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Graduation day 1969
item.description:
"Like many young people of my generation, I (Norma-Ann Coleman)was the first in my family to go to university and it was a proud day for all of us when I graduated. My mother looked very smart with a fashionable dress and coat brought in a rather up-market shop in Ayr. When she took her seat in the hall prior to the graduation ceremony, she was horrified to find that the lady sitting next to her was wearing an identical outfit. "We must have exquisite taste," they both muttered with clenched teeth.
Note that both my mother and my sister are wearing white gloves in the photograph. A lady never went anywhere without her gloves!"
item.author: Jean

item.title: Reading Plato with daffodil in hand 1968
item.description:
Norma-Ann Coleman ( nee Clayton) posing with Plato and daffodil in the grounds of University Hall, St Andrews.
"This photograph was taken during typical "exam weather" when it was too nice to stay indoors to study. We used to sit on the grass reading and deluding outselves that we were working as hard as we would have been in the University library. It was the time of poetry, Flower Power and Beautiful People and I couldn't resist trying to get in on the act. I loved my denim touser suit and felt really trendy in it."
item.author: Jean

item.title: On the catwalk at a "mannequin parade" 1959
item.description:
"My father, Douglas Clayton, was a councillor on Irvine Town Council and served on many local committees. To raise funds for elderly people in the town in the Joint Wards Old Folks Committe decided to hold what was called a "Mannequin Parade" and Dad persuaded several ladies' outfitters in the town to provide samples of the latest fashions for the amateur models to wear. Alas, I didn't get a party frock to model. My younger sister, Sandra, and I are pictured here wearing 'back to school' attire, a sensible duffle coat for her and a stunning trench coat and hat for me!
Note that all the ladies in the audience are wearing their best coats and hats for the occasion."
item.author: Jean

item.title: Paddling in the sea c1950
item.description:
Norma-Ann Coleman ( nee Clayton) and her uncle, Alex Miller testing the temperature of the water at Irvine Beach.
"Do you remember these elasticated swimming costumes? They were very tight and uncomfortable. I look quite relaxed here though paddling in the sea at Irvine with my uncle Alex who looks as if he could win a knobbly knees competition. His legs are even skinnier than mine! Unlike nearby Troon with its promenade and swimming pool, Irvine was not regarded as a seaside holiday resort but it had a lively, sandy beach and we loved to play in the sand dunes as children."
item.author: Jean

item.title: First photograph 1948
item.description: Norma-Ann Coleman ( nee Clayton,the elder daughter of Douglas and Norma Clayton, is obviously enjoying having her first formal photograph taken - in a studio in Glasgow. The family moved from Glasgow to Irvine, Ayshire in 1949.

item.title: School photograph 1910
item.description: Mary Freer McFarlane was born 28-May-1904 at Malloch's Close off the Canongate in Edinburgh. Her father Stephen tragically died in the Glasgow lodging house blaze on 19 November 1905. He had been working as a mason's labourer in Glasgow. Mary married James Nisbet on 28-Dec-1923. She worked as a bookbinder prior to the marriage. She died in 24-Sep-2002.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Diesel train engine driver c1950
item.description: Thomas (Tom) Blaikie donor' s (Vivienne Nisbet) father. He was born 30-Mar-1904 at Newtown St. Boswells, Roxburghshire became an engine driver after moving to Edinburgh. He had always worked on the railway since he was 14. He died at work on 1-Oct-1957 from a heart attack. He always went to work clean and tidy with shirt collar and tie showing above overalls and came home all dirt and grease from the engines.

item.title: Feeding hens outside the mill wages office c1902
item.description: The building behind the lady is still standing today but the other mill buildings were sold to pay for the liquidation of the company that owned them. They were bought by builders in Lanarkshire to build Blantyre, Hamilton, Cambuslang and places round and about with good dressed sandstone from all the buildings that were there becuase Blantyre Mill employed about 4,000 people. It was a big mill - huge - a cotton mill that had its own gasworks.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Redhall Mills dams head c1900
item.description:
Early 1900s or perhaps 1920s.
The stepping stones provided the only way to cross the river. When the mill was working the water went into the lade and the dam was dry so people could walk across. Lawrence Walker (donor) was carried by his mother across the stepping stones and up the steps at the side to go to the church at Colinton for his baptism. In the 1930s a bridge was built across the Water of Leith here which is still standing. The Corporaton of Edinburgh had the bridge built during the Depression to provide work and alleviate poverty. The bridge provided a vital link to save wet feet! They also employed people to make the walkway along the Water of Leith to Stockbridge and to take the millstones from the demolished Lindsay's Mill and set them up as a feature in the Dean Village. This was a kind of job creation project.
item.author: Ian ?

item.description: Remains of mill at the bottom of Colinton Dell. In the background is Redhall Mill sometimes known as Colinton Barley Mill. The wages office for the remains of the mill is on the left. It is still there, greatly improved, but the rest of the buildings have been demolished. The photograph is taken from the railway line that ran up to Balerno from Edinburgh.

item.title: Millbank House and Bogg's Mill c1900
item.description:
Bogg's Mill was run by the Walker family for a time. The donor (Lawrence Walker), who was born in 1928, spent his early childhood there. The family rented it from the estate - the Clarks of Auchendinny, who had Redhall House.
The photograph was taken from the banks of Redhall House. Someone from the Water of Leith Trust has identified Millbank House at the top of the brae from Bogg's Mill. This house is still there but all the Mill buildings were demolished by Edinburgh corporation in the 1950s. There is now a house built there called Riverside House.

Gideon Walker's initials (G.W.) can be seen on the sack The sack contained wood flour - sawdust. The mill was rebuilt in 1802 and on the left can be seen the stone arch of the previous building.

The tandem was still kept at Bell's Mill and birds nested in it until the explosion at the mill in 1971.

item.description: Careston castle, a private house, lies 5 miles west of Brechin. The name comes from a Viking raider Carl who died in a battle nearby.

item.description: The station is on the Brechin to Forfar line.

item.title: Careston Kirk 1890
item.description: The kirk is now renovated but looks very much the same. Lawrence Walker's (donor) great-great grandfather William Walker is buried in the churchyard.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Greenland Mill and employees 1880
item.description:
Lawrence Walker's (donor) grandfather Gideon Walker was the miller. He ground grain for animal feed by day and wood flour (sawdust) for industrial purposes, mainly linoleum, through the night.
The river was dammed at the Dean Vilage to make a lade (watercourse) that powered Lyndsay's Mill, then Marr's Mill, Greenland Mill, Stockbridge Mill, Silvermills, Cannonmills. Logie Green Mill, then on to Powerderhall Mill before going back to the river at Bonnington.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Greenland Mill 1880
item.description: This photograph was taken by Gideon Walker, through the arches of the Dean Bridge. Some of the mill workers can be seen by the wall and members of the public walking down to Stockbridge.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Greenlands mill below Dean Bridge and Lyndsay mill to right 1880
item.description:
Dean Bridge and Holy Trinity Kirk taken from the pleasure gardens of Belgrave Crescent. In the background are Great Stuart Street and Randolph Crescent at the west end of Edinburgh.
Through the middle arch can be seen Greenlands Mill, demolished in the 1900s. At the right hand is Lyndsay's flour mill demolished in the 1930s. One of the reasons for the demolition of the mills was that there had been an outbreak of cholera in the latter part of the 19th century. The authorities thought that the lade (watercourse) that powered the mills diverted too much water from the river. In warmer weather the shortage of water in the riverbed further downstream created a health hazard.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Family outside mill house c1890
item.description:
Ths photograph shows Gideon Walker and his wife Isobell with Thomas Allan (far right), Allan (far left), Jessie (middle), Helen (Nellie in front), Gideon Junior (known as Jockie on mother's knee).
The tree on the left is a boxtree, about a hundred years old at the time, and is still standing. Gideon Walker was the Lawrence Walker (donor's) grandfather and was the miller at Bell's Mill.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Kute Kids Concert Party chorus line 1938
item.description: This chorus line did song and dance routines - high kick and tap. Part of larger group of 5 to 15 year olds who entertained at various venues within the city and the Lothians - mostly for charity.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Publicity shot of two members of the Kute Kids Concert Party 1938
item.description: Marjorie (aged 8) and Frances (aged 13) were members of the Kute Kids Concert Party. They grew up at 225 Easter Road and practised at Abbeymount Halls. No mothers were allowed backstage.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: Monica Renton's Kute Kids Concert Party 1938
item.description: The children (5 to 14 year olds) in the Kute Kids Concert Party were mainly from Abbeyhill and Easter Road primary schools. They did a lot of charity work and also entertained at hospitals with the elderly or homeless. They also did fund raising for the war effort from 1939 onwards: battleship week, Spitfire week etc. They played at Whitefoord House, Craiglockhart Hospital, People's Palaceand at various hospitals, backgreen concerts etc. One of the songs they used to sing was The Fleet's in Port Again.
item.author: Ian ?

item.title: School overhead ball team 1936
item.description: Overhead ball was a popular pre World War 2 game. There were school leagues and a big rally at Wardie once a year for the Leith championship.

item.title: Kilted soldier from the Dandy Ninth Regiment (Royal Scots) c1915
item.description:
Thomas Stephen Robertson, born 1896 - died 1934.

The Royal Scots were also known as "First of foot, right of the line and the pride of the British army". The 9th (Territorial) Battalion (later after amalgamation with the 7th Battalion, known as the 7th/9th Battalion) was known as "The Dandy Ninth", being the only kilted battalion of this lowland regiment which was originally formed from highlanders who emigrated to the Edinburgh area. (ref: Wikipedia)

item.title: The Edinburgh Dynamos ladies' football team c1950
item.description:
Bet Adamson is on the first right on the first row.
The Edinburgh Dynamos ladies' football team didn't have a ground of their own and were not allowed to join the Scottish Football Association - they were female!
Women's football was more popular in Fife and the North of England.

item.description: John Maley aged four standing on top of the hen house at the back of his grandfather's house.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Shipmates 1944
item.description:
Bunny Glover (left) and Taffy Evans.
John Maley and Bunny Glover were shipmates in the same hut. They were both amateur boxers.
"At HMS Rajaliya a boxing ring had been errected in the centre of the camp and a boxing match arranged. Bunny and I being the same weight fought each other. I gained a points decision but didn't enjoy fighting my shipmate."
item.author: Jean

item.title: Leaving for home 1945
item.description: "The end of the war in the Far East. We joined an aircraft carrier at Trincomalee in Ceylon and were put ashore at Madras in India to await a ship to the UK."
item.author: Jean

item.title: Sailor during initial training 1942
item.description: John Maley was called up to join the fleet-air-arm in January 1942. "We would be here for a five week disciplinary course. Our instructor was a leading seaman (Hopkins) a suvivor from a destroyer. When we were leaving we shook his hand and told him how glad we were to be leaving. He said 'Some day you will wish you were back here.'"
item.author: Jean

item.title: Returning home from South Africa 1945
item.description: "We were homeward bound in the French troopship Ile-De-France which was then the fifth largest ship in the world and although it travelled thousands of miles during the second world war it was never once attacked. There were over five thousand personnel onboard."
item.author: Jean

item.title: Christmas in Ceylon 1944
item.author: Jean

item.title: Elephants bathing in river 1944
item.description: The Mahout ( elephant keeper) would bring their elephants down to the river to bathe. The women are doing their washing by bashing the cloths against the rocks to clean them.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Carrier aircraft ready for action 1941
item.description: On every ship or shore base there was a ship's photographer and any action that a ship was in they would be up on deck taking photographs.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Merchant ship on fire 1941-42
item.description: Merchant ship on fire in the Atlantic. When a merchant ship was sunk the crew's pay was stopped until they aquired another ship.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Sailors in front of palm built huts 1944
item.description: John Maley (centre) with Norman Ellis (left) and Jocky Robertson (right) in front of palm built huts. When the monsoon season came "you never seen anything like it, not a gentle rain but a torrential rain battering on the roofs of your hut causing puddles all over."
item.author: Jean

item.title: Warspite, Barham and Valiant battleships under attack 1941-42
item.description:
The Warspite, Barham and the Valiant under attack in the Mediterranean. They sank three Italian cruisers at the battle of Matapan, Greece.
The Valiant was decommissioned in July 1945
The Braham was sunk on the 25th November 1941 by a German submarine.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Carrier task force at sea 1941
item.author: Jean

item.title: United States Navy sailor 1914-18
item.description: The photograph is of Jim Maley who served as a Gob (slang term for salor) in the First World War on board a battleship anchored in Brooklyn Navy dockyard. On one occasion Jim pulled out his hankie along with his roll of dollars from his small tunic pocket and his money landed in the water. He dived overboard and managed to retrieve his roll of dollar notes but was put in the cells for deserting his ship.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Machine gunner in the United States Army 1914-18
item.description: John Maley's uncle Pete Parnel, shown in the photograph, was a machine gunner in the United States Army. He was discharged from the army after being gassed. He returned to the USA but died a short time later from the effects of the gas.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Lumberjack and assembly line worker 1910
item.description: John Maley's farther worked as a lumberjack in Canada before moving to Detroit in America to work on the Ford assembly lines. Wages were thirty shilings a day whereas in the UK at that time they were thity shillings per week!
item.author: Jean

item.title: Military family 1870

item.description: The Maley family emigrated to America and Canada from Motherwell in the late 1800s. There were eleven in the family including mother and father.

item.title: School photograph 1930-31

In the back row next to their teacher (top row right)is Tommy Martin who was tragically killed by a bus while on his bike. This was when the coast line buses began running down to Seton Sands from St. Andrew Square.

item.author: Mark

item.title: Salvation Army girl 1930s
item.description: Beryl Reid was born in 1913. She told us - "I've been in The Salvation Army all my life. My mother was a Salvationist when she was young. We were all brought up to go to the Army. There's no drink allowed in the Army - teetotallers. You signed your name when you joined and you got your Articles of War with the Army flags on it. If you wanted to take it as your religion you signed it. I was collecting once for the Salvation Army in my uniform outside Jerome's the photographers in Leith Street. The women said, 'Come in and we'll take your photo for you.' They didn't charge me."

item.title: Grandchildren in their finery 1926
item.description: John Maley aged 7 ( front row right) and his two year old sister Elizabeth (front left) with their grandparents. John's grandfather's house was only ten feet from the seashore and when it was rough sea with high winds the sea would come in with force and strike the wall and windows.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Posing in front of chicken run 1926
item.description: John Maley is shown infront of his grandfather's chicken run. John's grandfather would hand him a pail of food stuff for the hens and shout to him, "Go on John make them run" and when he would throw it they would run and very nearly fly with flapping wings to the corner of the chicken run.

item.description: Although John Maley was an air mechanic on air frames, he enjoyed going up with pilots on test. His favourite plane was the open cockpit Swordfish affectionately known throughout the fleet as the "string bag".

item.title: Waverley Station 1950s
item.description: "My granddad was a boxer. He might have been the owner or manager of the Eldorado. One lady mentioned owner, but a group of men said he was the manager. He was a well travelled man, so my father had the opportunity to visit many foreign places. He was a writer and an artist and painted a lot of Salvadore Dali's paintings. As I remember he had all his paintings in his porch at Mountcastle."

item.title: John Codona, One Man Band c 1954
item.description: John Codona leading the local children along the Dumbiedykes. John Codona was a well-known Edinburgh character. This picture shows the steps leading down through the greens to the road. Luckily there were not many cars in those days as the children were apt to run straight into the road.
item.author: Jean

item.title: John Codona, One-Man Band c1954
item.description: This shows the largest concrete drying green adjacent to Dumbiedykes Lane. A square shelter was built here during the war.

item.title: Royal Enfield motorbike 1952
item.author: Jean

item.title: Family photo c1950
item.description: The donr's Auntie Mary and cousin Brian were on a visit from Kettering and the donor and her sister were boarded with another auntie to make room for the vistors. When the girls made a return visit on holiday by train they travelled by themselves in the charge of the guard, which was quite an adventure for them.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Boys on Bikes c1955
item.description: A group of pals (Dumbiedykes 'keelies' or street urchins) on their bikes outside Waterstone's paper shop opposite the bowling green, Dumbiedykes Road
item.author: Jean

item.title: Street Photo c 1950
item.description: Outside the family's first home in Dumbiedykes. It had gas but no electricity and certainly no central heating but it did have an inside toilet. When the family moved from 38 Dumbiedykes Road to number 42, they got electricity for the first time and they remember the bliss of switching on lights and having a real cooker.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Washing Green c1950
item.description: Peter Bottomley aged 3 in the washing green outside his home. You can see the layout of the washing greens and balconies. Steps led from the walkway down through the greens to the road below. Washing was always taken in at night and never hung out if there was a wedding or a funeral. The push chair was probably used to transport the laundry to and from the local wash house.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Coronation Day 1953
item.description: This picture was taken at Hen's Dyke, perhaps a local nickname for an elevated concrete 'green' with steps leading down to Dumbiedykes Road. At the back of the assembled neighbours, you can see the awnings of the local Co-op stores at the Holyrood end. The brick building at the right hand side of the picture is the local bleach works.
item.author: Jean

item.title: Coronation Day 1953
item.author: Jean

item.title: Coronation Day 1953
item.description: There were so many children in the Dumbiedykes that two parties were held.

On introduction in 'La France' magazine through the James Clark School (aged 11), the donor gave her father's occupation as brassmoulder and Monique gave hers as cutlery manufacturer but her dad owned the cutlery business. The donor visited them twice at Chatellerault, Vienne.

item.title: 1950s Ballantyne Rd. Leith.
item.description:
Mrs Dickson, Mr Charlie Dickson & Mary Robertson.
Charlie Dickson worked with the trawler company Carnie & Gibb of Granton. He was possibly the crewing manager.Both
he & Mr John (Jock) Robertson worked on the trawlers in Ayr
between 1940 & 1944 when fishing moved from the East coast to the West coast during WWII.
Ballantyne Rd. was demolished when the area was cleared in the 1970s.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: Mrs Mary Robertson 1940s
item.description:
Mrs Mary Robertson & amp; friends Jean Wilson & Mrs Cunningham
on the balcony of 19 Johnstone st.Leith.The building was owned by A&R Hepburn (Engineers) of Dock st. Leith.The tenement was built over Hepburns workshops.The balconies, 4 levels 5 houses per level,looked over to Dock St.The building had a flat roof with clothes drying facilities.

item.title: Braw Lad's Day 1933
item.description: The donor aged 16 months with his mother Annie Melrose and father Alex Melrose. This was probably one of the early 'Braw Lad's Days' which started in the 1930s. All the other border towns had their Common Riding days so Galashiels made up a parade with incidents from past history and ending up at the 1914 - 1918 war memorial. A Braw Lad and Lass are picked each year and there are ride-outs (on horseback), balls and many social events. They ride in all the other towns' events, including Musselburgh's 'Honest Lad'.

item.title: North Canongate School 1923
item.description: David Prior was born in 1916. He wrote "The woman on the left was our teacher, Miss Stuart. I'm sure she was dedicated to teaching. She taught my mother before me and later became the headmistress. The young woman on the right was a sudent teacher. Most of us pupils came from the poorer districts of Edinburgh and some, including myself, from actual slums. I remember our headmaster, a Mr Young, in his pre-holiday talk making sure to tell our mothers to use the fine-toothed comb. There was a lunch-time school meal - soup and two slices of bread cost one penny."
item.author: Gallery Administrator

The man in the photograph is Will Letters who was song writer to Flora Ford. The woman on the far left of the photograph is Goeorge's mother Mary McGregor Letters Kirk who entertained in picture houses as a singer and a dancer. The lady seated is Kitty Ballenby, Will's wife who was a professional dancer. The girl in the photo is Mary Kirk's daughter.

item.title: Restoration and Painting 1992
item.description: Until the mid 1980s, St Cuthbert's Coop - which became Scotmid - delivered milk by horse cart throughout Edinburgh. The company had a workshop which maintained the carts and also had the Royal Warrant for work on the Queen's coaches, which could be seen in Royal processions to and from Holyrood Palace. After the milk cart deliveries had been withdrawn, the coachworks continued to operate for several years and provided coaches for weddings and for Santa's procession at Christmas. Scotmid's collection of coaches included an impressive collection ranging from a stagecoach to a horse-drawn hearse. Several of these are now in the care of the Royal Scottish Museum. Scotmid eventually closed its coachworks in 1993, with the loss of the skills of high quality painting and upholstery. One of its last two workers then took up employment with Lothian Region Transport repairing bus seats. In this photograph one of the larger coaches has been dismantled and is undergoing thorough restoration with particular attention being paid to the quality of finish and paintwork.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: David Lindsay Stonemason 1995
item.description: This firm was responsible for restoring many old buildings in Edinburgh including St Bernard's Well, St John's Church and the Sheriff Court House in central Edinburgh.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: The Rich Tea Biscuit Line 1992
item.description: Burton's Biscuits is the largest manufacturer of Rich Tea Biscuits in Europe. It has a large workforce, which increases in the later months of the year as production of shortbread biscuits increases to meet the Christmas demand.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: Speedspools 1992
item.description: Speedspools was the last of the monotype printers to survive in Edinburgh. Output comprised mainly of specialist publications - such as the Bible in Gaelic. Harry MacIntosh, owner of the company had, over the years, acquired a large collection of old printing machinery and dies. He had writtem programs to transfer data from computer to paper tape, which was used as input to the monotype machinery shown here.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: Linotype Equipment 1992
item.description: In 1992, Baker and Claremont was the last surviving Linotype printers in Edinburgh. The large machinery used hot metal to create individual lines of type.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: Roof slating 1993
item.description: The building being re- slated here is in Thistle Court in the centre of Edinburgh. It is a small two-storey building built in 1767 - the first to be constructed as part of James Craig's master plan for the New Town of Edinburgh. The photograph was taken looking down on the roof from one of the many high office blocks surrounding the site. The slaters spent several weeks re-slating this intricate roof.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: Working in the Dry Docks 1992
item.description: Alexandra Dry Docks were constructed in the mid 19th Century as part of the continuing expansion of Leith docks. By 1937, there were 8 dry docks. By 2000, only three remained and this one was rarely used. The workers in this picture are probably employees of the marine engineering firm George Brown & Sons, at that time the oldest privately owned company in Leith.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: Casting Railings 1993
item.description: Charles Laing established Laing's foundry in 1920. In 2011, his grandson Andrew manages the business. The firm moved to premises in Beaverbank Road in 1943.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: Rolling Barrels 1991
item.description: The NB Distillery makes large quantities of grain whisky for blending. This photograph looks down from the distillery into the cooperage yard. The site also had bonded warehouses, facilities for filling barrels and a small cooperage which has since closed.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: New Edinburgh Sewers 1991
item.description: This photograph was taken near the end of a 300 metre tunnel being constructed beneath central Edinburgh. Work was carried out in 12 hour shifts, 6 days per week. The conditions were very cramped. The tunnel progressed by blasting and drilling by hand, then it was lined with panels and cemented. As the cement dried, conditions became very hot. The work was completed in early 1992 and the ground above was developed as part of Edinburgh's new financial district.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: Self-employed Farrier 1992
item.description:
This self-employed farrier is based at Fauldhouse in West Lothian and travels to local farms in his Mini van with its equipment and range of horseshoes in many sizes. He visits most farms every week or fortnight. Each horse needs to be shod about once evcery 6 weeks.
Westmuir Farm overlooks the Forth Bridges and stables about 40 horses.

item.title: Terrace of Cribs 1938
item.description: Elsie Inglis Memorial Hospital was founded in 1925 at Abbeyhill in memory of Elsie Inglis, pioneering woman doctor who saw active service during the First World War. She always advocated better medical care for women and was politically involved with women’s causes. It was a maternity hospital, affectionately known as “Elsie’s” by generations of women who had their babies there. A daily dose of fresh air was clearly seen as essential provision for healthy babies.

item.title: Posing with the car 1920
item.description: The Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh was founded in 1670 as a physic garden on a small patch of land in Holyrood Park. Subsequent sites were at the head of the Nor’ Loch where the Waverley Station now stands and near the top of Leith Walk. The present site at Inverleith was established in 1820.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: Barbara Jeffrey 1951
item.description: Notice the ruched swimming costume and the Mickey Mouse bucket. 160,000 prefabricated houses, affectionately known as prefabs, sprang up around Britain following the Second World War to tackle the desperate shortage of houses. They were designed to last for up to ten years but many were still standing sixty years later. There were groups of prefabs at several locations around Edinburgh including West Pilton, Saughton, Oxgangs, Greendykes and Gilmerton. Many couples were happy to live in their prefab for the whole of their married life.

item.title: Gordon Highlander Officers 1912
item.description: William Mudie Downie (the donor's father) is in the centre of the back row. He was very ill when he returned from India and supposedly dying, but he recovered and married soon afterwards. During the time of the expanding British Empire in the late 19th century the Gordon Highlanders served on the frontiers of India, Egypt, Sudan and South Africa. In 1880 they succeeded in marching over 320 miles across demanding territory in Afghanistan in a remarkable 23 days. They achieved a celebrated victory on the Heights of Dargai on India’s North-West Frontier. During World War I 50,000 Gordons served in the regular, territorial and service battalions, notably at the Battle of the Somme.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: William Mudie Downie 1916
item.description: The donor's father photographed in Southern Ireland during the First World War. The Gordon Highlanders regiment was formed in 1794 by the 4th Duke of Gordon as a regiment of Highland Foot (Infantry). They saw action against the armies of France, first in Holland, then in Egypt and in the Peninsular War in Spain. The regiment played a prominent role in the final defeat of Napoleon at Waterloo in 1815.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: A Forces Wedding Party 1945
item.description: This bride was quite unusual in being married in full bridal regalia at her wartime wedding, as fabric was often not available and funds were sometimes tight. It was common, though, for the groom and his best man to be in uniform.
item.author: Gallery Administrator

item.title: Girl in ATS Uniform 1943
item.description: The ATS was the forerunner of the British Royal Women’s Army Corps. It came into being by Royal Warrant in September 1938 and the following year Britain’s declaration of war as transmitted by an ATS operator but it was not until April 1941 that the ATS was given equal military status with men. They continued, however, to be paid tw-thirds of the pay of men of the same rank.

item.description: Aircrews risked their lives to bring back thousands of detailed aerial photographs during WWII. Many hours would then be spent plotting locations on maps of enemy territory to give allied invasion forces the best chance of successful missions.

item.title: Parsons Peebles Home Guard 1939
item.description: Originally Bruce Peebles was a major employer in the Granton area between 1904, when the company moved to East Pilton, and 1999 when the works closed following a large- scale fire. Gas lighting equipment was manufactured, followed by electrical products, including dynamos. During the 1914-18 war munitions were made and in the Second World War searchlights and mobile transformers were produced and minesweeping equipment for the navy. King George VI and Queen Elizabeth visited the works in 1942 and again in 1944, recognising the company’s contribution to the war effort. A company merger in 1969 resulted in the change of name to Parsons Peebles DTL Broxburn.
